newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU clears extension of Finnish ship aid schemes.
newsitem.headline: EU clears extension of Finnish ship aid schemes.

text.p: The European Commission decided on Tuesday to approve the prolongation of two Finnish aid schemes for shipbuilding.

One of the schemes concern contract-related production aid for vessels to be built at Finnish yards. "The Finnish government has set the total amount of subsidy at 350 million markka," the Commission said in a statement.

The other scheme grants tax concessions for ice-breakers that applies to shipowners. The aid consists of a reduction of an amount equivalent to three percent of the acquisition costs of the vessel from the shipping company's taxable income.

"The prolongation of these two Finnish aid schemes for shipbuilding is valid for contracts signed before the OECD agreement concerning aid to shipbuilding comes into force or at the latest 31 December 1997," the Commission said.
The Finnish proposal does not introduce any new aid measures, the Commission added, and the Finnish government has undertaken not to exceed the EU aid ceiling.
In December, the Commission decided to maintain EU shipbuilding aid ceilings until the end of 1997, if an international deal to scrap most support to the sector had not come into force before then.
The 1994 agreement forged by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development has not yet been ratified by the United States.
